thread.title: INLAND: 5 reasons why economy firing on all cylinders
thread.title_full: INLAND: 5 reasons why economy firing on all cylinders - Press Enterprise

author: DEBRA GRUSZECKI
title: INLAND: 5 reasons why economy firing on all cylinders
text:
BY DEBRA GRUSZECKI Oct. 1, 2015 Updated: 5:43 p.m. INLAND: 5 reasons why economy firing on all cylinders Print Photo Share Pin It More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Related article » NATIONAL OUTLOOK
Positive Trends: Rebounding housing market. European economy improving. Low commodity prices spurring consumer spending.
Concerning Trends: Income inequality. Tough mortgage credit rules. Depressed new home construction. Unexplained market volatility.
CALIFORNIA OUTLOOK
Positive Trends: A bright spot in the U.S. economy. Labor force growing half-again as fast as the entire nation. Jobs quality rising. Wages bumping up. Home sales, equity improving.
Concerning Trends: Middle-income industries yet to see significant growth; below pre-recession levels. Construction still down roughly 180,000 jobs from peak.
INLAND OUTLOOK
Positive Trends: Real estate, labor market on firmer ground. Affordability a lynchpin for growth. Most economic indicators point to upward trajectory.
Concerning Trends: Housing supply inadequate for expected population gains. Developers face unfriendly regulatory environment.
The Inland Southern California economy is firing on all cylinders, analysts for UC Riverside’s new Center for Economic Forecasting and Development said Thursday.
Research director Jordan Levine said this region of 4 million-plus people is well past triage mode and is in the No. 3 spot for job growth, right behind San Francisco and San Jose.
Consumers are spending money. Home prices and home sales are on the rise. Builders are digging into the mix. Job quality is improving. Wage growth is kicking in.
And the $133.9 billion Inland economy that’s about the same size as Pittsburgh, Tampa and Indianapolis today is growing faster than most of the Top 10 metros in the nation.
5 TAKEAWAYS FROM UC RIVERSIDE ECONOMIC FORECAST
Economist Jordan Levine said Thursday at UC Riverside’s annual economic forecast that the Inland area is “punching above our weight.” Here’s why.
Economic strength
The region’s gross domestic product has been growing for five years; we’re now the nation’s 24th largest economy.
5 TAKEAWAYS FROM UC RIVERSIDE ECONOMIC FORECAST
Economist Jordan Levine said Thursday at UC Riverside’s annual economic forecast that the Inland area is “punching above our weight.” Here’s why.
More jobs
The area has recovered from the recession and now is looking at 3 percent growth for at least the next two years.
5 TAKEAWAYS FROM UC RIVERSIDE ECONOMIC FORECAST
Economist Jordan Levine said Thursday at UC Riverside’s annual economic forecast that the Inland area is “punching above our weight.” Here’s why.
More careers
Everybody knows logistics is strong, but other sectors are emerging: Among them manufacturing and tech.
5 TAKEAWAYS FROM UC RIVERSIDE ECONOMIC FORECAST
Economist Jordan Levine said Thursday at UC Riverside’s annual economic forecast that the Inland area is “punching above our weight.” Here’s why.
Housing
Look for steady double-digit growth – at least 8 to 12 percent – in home prices in the months ahead.
5 TAKEAWAYS FROM UC RIVERSIDE ECONOMIC FORECAST
Economist Jordan Levine said Thursday at UC Riverside’s annual economic forecast that the Inland area is “punching above our weight.” Here’s why.
Housing affordability
The median price of a home is below 30 percent of the region’s median household income.
The outlook, the first forecast to come out of the newly formed center by Levine and its new director, Christopher Thornberg, paints a region the nation once looked upon as the housing bust’s Ground Zero as a place where there’s been GDP growth of nearly 3.5 percent.
“Every sector is growing,” Levine said, and the Inland’s strides are broad-based. “We are far from being a one-trick pony. We are not just an area with cheap dirt.”
Levine, one of the forecast’s lead authors, said the labor market has recovered, and the jobless rate – 6.4 percent – is chipping down at a faster clip than the rest of the state.
Taxable sales growth – it climbed 5.7 percent to $16.5 billion in the first quarter of 2015 from the same period in 2014 – was higher in the Inland region than it Orange and Los Angeles counties. Hotel revenue is up 12 percent.
Tourism is on the rise.
And the population has grown by 1.1 percent, faster than Los Angeles County – from January 2014 to January 2015.
The forecast said affordable residential and commercial real estate in the region will continue to attract more residents and contribute to the region’s success moving forward.
Median price on existing homes, though rising 6 percent to $282,652 in the second quarter in the Inland region, is still far lower than coastal counties like Los Angeles, where the median was $507,349, or the pricier Orange County, where the median hit $660,263.
Thornberg and Levine predict population in the Inland region will grow at a pace of 1.8 percent in 2016, and then at a rate of 2 percent.
Through 2020, the forecast says this will be the affordable housing destination for Southern California. It will be a new hub to multiple employment centers, the forecast says.
